body: I didn't know biases were more stable to higher LRs. Thanks

@pfeatherstone ah no, the biases are not more stable at higher LRs. I meant that you can apply a higher LR to the biases without the losses becoming unstable. If you applied similar higher LRs to the weights the model would become unstable. This may be because there are simply fewer biases than weights, or because their gradients are more highly correlated to the loss. The last layer output biases have a partial derivative of 1.0 with respect to the loss for example, so changing these directly impacts the loss.

There are as many biases as convolutional kernels. All the [conv] blocks in yolo except 3 have batchnorm layers and no biases, but each batchnorm layer has a bias. The remaining [conv] blocks have biases. So there should be exactly the same number of biases as kernels.
I'll take your word for it that the gradients are more stable. Interesting phenomenon though

@pfeatherstone ah yes, but for example for a Conv2d() with 512x256x3x3 there will be a million weights and only 512 biases. From the model_info report, if you set verbose=True you will see:

```
layer                                     name  gradient   parameters                shape         mu      sigma
...
   90                         42.Conv2d.weight      True  1.17965e+06     [512, 256, 3, 3]  -9.26e-06      0.012
   91                    42.BatchNorm2d.weight      True          512                [512]          1          0
   92                      42.BatchNorm2d.bias      True          512                [512]          0          0
```

Rather than opening a separate issue i'll continue asking questions here.
i've noticed you have a bunch of other config files based on yolov3-spp.
What were the results of your experiments with:
yolov3-spp3.cfg
yolov3-spp-matrix.cfg
yolov4-tiny.cfg
?
Have you found any benefits in doing warm restarts in your cosine annealing?
During training, why do you not always set the target objectness to 1, instead you set to``` 1 + model.gr * (giou - 1)``` where gr scales between 0 and 1 during burnin?

Also, I just noticed that your scheduling is very similar to OneCycleLR in torch.optim.lr_scheduler. It pretty much burns-in to a maximum learning rate then anneals. This applies to lr and momentum. So it seems to be very similar to what you're doing.

@pfeatherstone the cfgs are experimental changes. yolov3-spp3 applies spp to each yolo output, matrix attemps to recreate matrixnets, yolov4-tiny is an update we are working on which uses 3 output layers and updated anchors. yolov4-tiny works better in most situations than yolov3-tiny, the other two we were not able to demonstrate improvements.

Warm restarts did not help in our experiments.

Objectness targets of 1 were the default before, but we have set them to the giou to assist in NMS box ordering. model.gr helps to phase in the predicted giou values, because at the beginning they may be unreliable.

I have not looked at onecyclelr, thanks for the recommendation. Do you have a link to it's results?
If you go to the pytorch docs and OneCycleLr, there is a link to the paper. it seems to be very similar to what you’re doing.
I’ve also found warm restarts not to help. It seems you loose all momentum. Maybe if there was a slow ramp up at the beginning of each restart but not convinced.

> @pfeatherstone the cfgs are experimental changes. yolov3-spp3 applies spp to each yolo output, matrix attemps to recreate matrixnets, yolov4-tiny is an update we are working on which uses 3 output layers and updated anchors. yolov4-tiny works better in most situations than yolov3-tiny, the other two we were not able to demonstrate improvements.
> 
> Warm restarts did not help in our experiments.
> 
> Objectness targets of 1 were the default before, but we have set them to the giou to assist in NMS box ordering. model.gr helps to phase in the predicted giou values, because at the beginning they may be unreliable.
> 
> I have not looked at onecyclelr, thanks for the recommendation. Do you have a link to it's results?

Did you have any success with matrixnets ?
